texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Getting started with Red Hat AI Inference Server
texts.text: Getting started with Red Hat AI Inference Server

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Learn how to work with Red Hat AI Inference Server for model serving and inferencing.
texts.text: Learn how to work with Red Hat AI Inference Server for model serving and inferencing.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Preface Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: Preface Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Red Hat AI Inference Server is a container image that optimizes serving and inferencing with LLMs. Using AI Inference Server, you can serve and inference models in a way that boosts their performance while reducing their costs.
texts.text: Red Hat AI Inference Server is a container image that optimizes serving and inferencing with LLMs. Using AI Inference Server, you can serve and inference models in a way that boosts their performance while reducing their costs.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Chapter 1. About AI Inference Server Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: Chapter 1. About AI Inference Server Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: AI Inference Server provides enterprise-grade stability and security, building on upstream, open source software. AI Inference Server leverages the upstream
texts.text: AI Inference Server provides enterprise-grade stability and security, building on upstream, open source software. AI Inference Server leverages the upstream

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For example, AI Inference Server uses continuous batching to process requests as they arrive instead of waiting for a full batch to be accumulated. It also uses tensor parallelism to distribute LLM workloads across multiple GPUs. These features provide reduced latency and higher throughput.
texts.text: For example, AI Inference Server uses continuous batching to process requests as they arrive instead of waiting for a full batch to be accumulated. It also uses tensor parallelism to distribute LLM workloads across multiple GPUs. These features provide reduced latency and higher throughput.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: To reduce the cost of inferencing models, AI Inference Server uses paged attention. LLMs use a mechanism called attention to understand conversations with users. Normally, attention uses a significant amount of memory, much of which is wasted. Paged attention addresses this memory wastage by provisioning memory for LLMs similar to the way that virtual memory works for operating systems. This approach consumes less memory, which lowers costs.
texts.text: To reduce the cost of inferencing models, AI Inference Server uses paged attention. LLMs use a mechanism called attention to understand conversations with users. Normally, attention uses a significant amount of memory, much of which is wasted. Paged attention addresses this memory wastage by provisioning memory for LLMs similar to the way that virtual memory works for operating systems. This approach consumes less memory, which lowers costs.

texts.text: To verify cost savings and performance gains with AI Inference Server, complete the following procedures:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Serve and inference a large language model with Red Hat AI Inference Server.
texts.text: Serve and inference a large language model with Red Hat AI Inference Server.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You have installed Podman or Docker
texts.text: You have installed Podman or Docker

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You have access to a Linux server with NVIDIA or AMD GPUs and are logged in as a user with root privileges
texts.text: You have access to a Linux server with NVIDIA or AMD GPUs and are logged in as a user with root privileges

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You have access to registry.redhat.io and have logged in
texts.text: You have access to registry.redhat.io and have logged in

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You have a Hugging Face account and have generated a Hugging Face token
texts.text: You have a Hugging Face account and have generated a Hugging Face token

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For more information about supported quantization schemes for accelerators, see
texts.text: For more information about supported quantization schemes for accelerators, see

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Identify the correct image for your infrastructure. AI Accelerator AI Inference Server image NVIDIA CUDA registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0-1754088865-hotfix-1 AMD ROCm registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-rocm-rhel9:3.2.0
texts.text: Identify the correct image for your infrastructure. AI Accelerator AI Inference Server image NVIDIA CUDA registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0-1754088865-hotfix-1 AMD ROCm registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-rocm-rhel9:3.2.0

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Open a terminal on your server host, and log in to registry.redhat.io : podman login registry.redhat.io $ podman login registry.redhat.io Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: Open a terminal on your server host, and log in to registry.redhat.io : podman login registry.redhat.io $ podman login registry.redhat.io Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Pull the relevant image for your GPUs:
texts.text: Pull the relevant image for your GPUs:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If your system has SELinux enabled, configure SELinux to allow device access: sudo setsebool -P container_use_devices 1 $ sudo setsebool -P container_use_devices 1 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: If your system has SELinux enabled, configure SELinux to allow device access: sudo setsebool -P container_use_devices 1 $ sudo setsebool -P container_use_devices 1 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Create a volume and mount it into the container. Adjust the container permissions so that the container can use it. mkdir -p rhaiis-cache $ mkdir -p rhaiis-cache Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow chmod g+rwX rhaiis-cache $ chmod g+rwX rhaiis-cache Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: Create a volume and mount it into the container. Adjust the container permissions so that the container can use it. mkdir -p rhaiis-cache $ mkdir -p rhaiis-cache Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow chmod g+rwX rhaiis-cache $ chmod g+rwX rhaiis-cache Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Create or append your HF_TOKEN Hugging Face token to the private.env file. Source the private.env file. echo "export HF_TOKEN=<your_HF_token>" > private.env $ echo "export HF_TOKEN=<your_HF_token>" > private.env Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow source private.env $ source private.env Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: Create or append your HF_TOKEN Hugging Face token to the private.env file. Source the private.env file. echo "export HF_TOKEN=<your_HF_token>" > private.env $ echo "export HF_TOKEN=<your_HF_token>" > private.env Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow source private.env $ source private.env Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Start the AI Inference Server container image.
texts.text: Start the AI Inference Server container image.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In a separate tab in your terminal, make a request to your model with the API. curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "prompt": "What is the capital of France?", "max_tokens": 50 }' http://<your_server_ip>:8000/v1/completions | jq curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "prompt": "What is the capital of France?", "max_tokens": 50 }' http://<your_server_ip>:8000/v1/completions | jq Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Example output { "id": "cmpl-b84aeda1d5a4485c9cb9ed4a13072fca", "object": "text_completion", "created": 1746555421, "model": "RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8", "choices": [ { "index": 0, "text": " Paris.\nThe capital of France is Paris.", "logprobs": null, "finish_reason": "stop", "stop_reason": null, "prompt_logprobs": null } ], "usage": { "prompt_tokens": 8, "total_tokens": 18, "completion_tokens": 10, "prompt_tokens_details": null } } { "id": "cmpl-b84aeda1d5a4485c9cb9ed4a13072fca", "object": "text_completion", "created": 1746555421, "model": "RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8", "choices": [ { "index": 0, "text": " Paris.\nThe capital of France is Paris.", "logprobs": null, "finish_reason": "stop", "stop_reason": null, "prompt_logprobs": null } ], "usage": { "prompt_tokens": 8, "total_tokens": 18, "completion_tokens": 10, "prompt_tokens_details": null } } Copy to Clipboard Copied! texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Chapter 4. Validating Red Hat AI Inference Server benefits using key metrics Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: Chapter 4. Validating Red Hat AI Inference Server benefits using key metrics Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Use the following metrics to evaluate the performance of the LLM model being served with AI Inference Server:
texts.text: Use the following metrics to evaluate the performance of the LLM model being served with AI Inference Server:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Time to first token (TTFT) : How long does it take for the model to provide the first token of its response?
texts.text: Time to first token (TTFT) : How long does it take for the model to provide the first token of its response?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Time per output token (TPOT) : How long does it take for the model to provide an output token to each user, who has sent a request?
texts.text: Time per output token (TPOT) : How long does it take for the model to provide an output token to each user, who has sent a request?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Latency : How long does it take for the model to generate a complete response?
texts.text: Latency : How long does it take for the model to generate a complete response?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Throughput : How many output tokens can a model produce simultaneously, across all users and requests?
texts.text: Throughput : How many output tokens can a model produce simultaneously, across all users and requests?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Complete the procedure below to run a benchmark test that shows how AI Inference Server, and other inference servers, perform according to these metrics.
texts.text: Complete the procedure below to run a benchmark test that shows how AI Inference Server, and other inference servers, perform according to these metrics.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: On your host system, start an AI Inference Server container and serve a model. podman run --rm -it --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ --security-opt=label=disable \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 $ podman run --rm -it --device nvidia.com/gpu = all \ --shm-size = 4GB -p 8000 :8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN= $HF_TOKEN " \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ --security-opt = label = disable \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: On your host system, start an AI Inference Server container and serve a model. podman run --rm -it --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ --security-opt=label=disable \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 $ podman run --rm -it --device nvidia.com/gpu = all \ --shm-size = 4GB -p 8000 :8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN= $HF_TOKEN " \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ --security-opt = label = disable \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In a separate terminal tab, install the benchmark tool dependencies. pip install vllm pandas datasets $ pip install vllm pandas datasets Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: In a separate terminal tab, install the benchmark tool dependencies. pip install vllm pandas datasets $ pip install vllm pandas datasets Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: text
texts.orig: : git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git $ git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: : git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git $ git clone https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm.git Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Run the ./vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py script. python vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py --backend vllm --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 --num-prompts 100 --dataset-name random --random-input 1024 --random-output 512 --port 8000 $ python vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py --backend vllm --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 --num-prompts 100 --dataset-name random --random-input 1024 --random-output 512 --port 8000 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: Run the ./vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py script. python vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py --backend vllm --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 --num-prompts 100 --dataset-name random --random-input 1024 --random-output 512 --port 8000 $ python vllm/benchmarks/benchmark_serving.py --backend vllm --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 --num-prompts 100 --dataset-name random --random-input 1024 --random-output 512 --port 8000 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.orig:
============ Serving Benchmark Result ============
Successful requests:                    100
Benchmark duration (s):                 4.61
Total input tokens:                     102300
Total generated tokens:                 40493
Request throughput (req/s):             21.67
Output token throughput (tok/s):        8775.85
Total Token throughput (tok/s):         30946.83
---------------Time to First Token----------------
Mean TTFT (ms):                         193.61
Median TTFT (ms):                       193.82
P99 TTFT (ms):                          303.90
-----Time per Output Token (excl. 1st token)------
Mean TPOT (ms):                         9.06
Median TPOT (ms):                       8.57
P99 TPOT (ms):                          13.57
---------------Inter-token Latency----------------
Mean ITL (ms):                          8.54
Median ITL (ms):                        8.49
P99 ITL (ms):                           13.14
==================================================

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Try changing the parameters of this benchmark and running it again. Notice how vllm as a backend compares to other options. Throughput should be consistently higher, while latency should be lower.
texts.text: Try changing the parameters of this benchmark and running it again. Notice how vllm as a backend compares to other options. Throughput should be consistently higher, while latency should be lower.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Chapter 5. Troubleshooting Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: Chapter 5. Troubleshooting Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The following troubleshooting information for Red Hat AI Inference Server 3.2 describes common problems related to model loading, memory, model response quality, networking, and GPU drivers. Where available, workarounds for common issues are described.
texts.text: The following troubleshooting information for Red Hat AI Inference Server 3.2 describes common problems related to model loading, memory, model response quality, networking, and GPU drivers. Where available, workarounds for common issues are described.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Most common issues in vLLM relate to installation, model loading, memory management, and GPU communication. Most problems can be resolved by using a correctly configured environment, ensuring compatible hardware and software versions, and following the recommended configuration practices.
texts.text: Most common issues in vLLM relate to installation, model loading, memory management, and GPU communication. Most problems can be resolved by using a correctly configured environment, ensuring compatible hardware and software versions, and following the recommended configuration practices.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For persistent issues, export VLLM_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG to enable debug logging and then check the logs.
texts.text: For persistent issues, export VLLM_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG to enable debug logging and then check the logs.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.1. Model loading errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.1. Model loading errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When you run the Red Hat AI Inference Server container image without specifying a user namespace, an unrecognized model error is returned. podman run --rm -it \ --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --security-opt=label=disable \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ --env=VLLM_NO_USAGE_STATS=1 \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 podman run --rm -it \ --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --security-opt=label=disable \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ --env=VLLM_NO_USAGE_STATS=1 \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Example output ValueError: Unrecognized model in RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8. Should have a model_type key in its config.json ValueError: Unrecognized model in RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8. Should have a model_type key in its config.json Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow To resolve this error, pass --userns=keep-id:uid=1001 as a Podman parameter to ensure that the container runs with the root user.
texts.text: When you run the Red Hat AI Inference Server container image without specifying a user namespace, an unrecognized model error is returned. podman run --rm -it \ --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --security-opt=label=disable \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ --env=VLLM_NO_USAGE_STATS=1 \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 podman run --rm -it \ --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \ --security-opt=label=disable \ --shm-size=4GB -p 8000:8000 \ --env "HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN=$HF_TOKEN" \ --env "HF_HUB_OFFLINE=0" \ --env=VLLM_NO_USAGE_STATS=1 \ -v ./rhaiis-cache:/opt/app-root/src/.cache \ registry.redhat.io/rhaiis/vllm-cuda-rhel9:3.2.0 \ --model RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8 Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Example output ValueError: Unrecognized model in RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8. Should have a model_type key in its config.json ValueError: Unrecognized model in RedHatAI/Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct-FP8. Should have a model_type key in its config.json Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow To resolve this error, pass --userns=keep-id:uid=1001 as a Podman parameter to ensure that the container runs with the root user.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sometimes when Red Hat AI Inference Server downloads the model, the download fails or gets stuck. To prevent the model download from hanging, first download the model using the huggingface-cli . For example: huggingface-cli download <MODEL_ID> --local-dir <DOWNLOAD_PATH> $ huggingface-cli download < MODEL_ID > --local-dir < DOWNLOAD_PATH > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow When serving the model, pass the local model path to vLLM to prevent the model from being downloaded again.
texts.text: Sometimes when Red Hat AI Inference Server downloads the model, the download fails or gets stuck. To prevent the model download from hanging, first download the model using the huggingface-cli . For example: huggingface-cli download <MODEL_ID> --local-dir <DOWNLOAD_PATH> $ huggingface-cli download < MODEL_ID > --local-dir < DOWNLOAD_PATH > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow When serving the model, pass the local model path to vLLM to prevent the model from being downloaded again.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When Red Hat AI Inference Server loads a model from disk, the process sometimes hangs. Large models consume memory, and if memory runs low, the system slows down as it swaps data between RAM and disk. Slow network file system speeds or a lack of available memory can trigger excessive swapping. This can happen in clusters where file systems are shared between cluster nodes. Where possible, store the model in a local disk to prevent slow down during model loading. Ensure that the system has sufficient CPU memory available. Ensure that your system has enough CPU capacity to handle the model.
texts.text: When Red Hat AI Inference Server loads a model from disk, the process sometimes hangs. Large models consume memory, and if memory runs low, the system slows down as it swaps data between RAM and disk. Slow network file system speeds or a lack of available memory can trigger excessive swapping. This can happen in clusters where file systems are shared between cluster nodes. Where possible, store the model in a local disk to prevent slow down during model loading. Ensure that the system has sufficient CPU memory available. Ensure that your system has enough CPU capacity to handle the model.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sometimes, Red Hat AI Inference Server fails to inspect the model. Errors are reported in the log. For example: #... File "vllm/model_executor/models/registry.py", line xxx, in \_raise_for_unsupported raise ValueError( ValueError: Model architectures [''] failed to be inspected. Please check the logs for more details. #... File "vllm/model_executor/models/registry.py", line xxx, in \_raise_for_unsupported raise ValueError( ValueError: Model architectures [''] failed to be inspected. Please check the logs for more details. Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow The error occurs when vLLM fails to import the model file, which is usually related to missing dependencies or outdated binaries in the vLLM build.
texts.text: Sometimes, Red Hat AI Inference Server fails to inspect the model. Errors are reported in the log. For example: #... File "vllm/model_executor/models/registry.py", line xxx, in \_raise_for_unsupported raise ValueError( ValueError: Model architectures [''] failed to be inspected. Please check the logs for more details. #... File "vllm/model_executor/models/registry.py", line xxx, in \_raise_for_unsupported raise ValueError( ValueError: Model architectures [''] failed to be inspected. Please check the logs for more details. Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow The error occurs when vLLM fails to import the model file, which is usually related to missing dependencies or outdated binaries in the vLLM build.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sometimes a runtime error occurs for certain hardware when you load 8-bit floating point (FP8) models. FP8 requires GPU hardware acceleration. Errors occur when you load FP8 models like deepseek-r1 or models tagged with the F8_E4M3 tensor type. For example: triton.compiler.errors.CompilationError: at 1:0: def \_per_token_group_quant_fp8( \^ ValueError("type fp8e4nv not supported in this architecture. The supported fp8 dtypes are ('fp8e4b15', 'fp8e5')") [rank0]:[W502 11:12:56.323757996 ProcessGroupNCCL.cpp:1496] Warning: WARNING: destroy_process_group() was not called before program exit, which can leak resources. For more info, please see https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/distributed.html#shutdown (function operator()) triton.compiler.errors.CompilationError: at 1:0: def \_per_token_group_quant_fp8( \^ ValueError("type fp8e4nv not supported in this architecture. The supported fp8 dtypes are ('fp8e4b15', 'fp8e5')") [rank0]:[W502 11:12:56.323757996 ProcessGroupNCCL.cpp:1496] Warning: WARNING: destroy_process_group() was not called before program exit, which can leak resources. For more info, please see https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/distributed.html#shutdown (function operator()) Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Note Review

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sometimes when serving a model a runtime error occurs that is related to the host system. For example, you might see errors in the log like this: INFO 05-07 19:15:17 [config.py:1901] Chunked prefill is enabled with max_num_batched_tokens=2048. OMP: Error #179: Function Can't open SHM failed: OMP: System error #0: Success Traceback (most recent call last): File "/opt/app-root/bin/vllm", line 8, in <module> sys.exit(main()) .......................... raise RuntimeError("Engine core initialization failed. " RuntimeError: Engine core initialization failed. See root cause above. INFO 05-07 19:15:17 [config.py:1901] Chunked prefill is enabled with max_num_batched_tokens=2048. OMP: Error #179: Function Can't open SHM failed: OMP: System error #0: Success Traceback (most recent call last): File "/opt/app-root/bin/vllm", line 8, in <module> sys.exit(main()) .......................... raise RuntimeError("Engine core initialization failed. " RuntimeError: Engine core initialization failed. See root cause above. Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow You can work around this issue by passing the --shm-size=2g argument when starting vllm .

OMP: Error #179: Function Can't open SHM failed: OMP: System error #0: Success Traceback (most recent call last): File "/opt/app-root/bin/vllm", line 8, in <module> sys.exit(main()) .......................... raise RuntimeError("Engine core initialization failed. " RuntimeError: Engine core initialization failed. See root cause above. Copy to Clipboard Copied! texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.2. Memory optimization Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.2. Memory optimization Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the model is too large to run with a single GPU, you will get out-of-memory (OOM) errors. Use memory optimization options such as quantization, tensor parallelism, or reduced precision to reduce the memory consumption. For more information, see
texts.text: If the model is too large to run with a single GPU, you will get out-of-memory (OOM) errors. Use memory optimization options such as quantization, tensor parallelism, or reduced precision to reduce the memory consumption. For more information, see

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.3. Generated model response quality Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.3. Generated model response quality Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In some scenarios, the quality of the generated model responses might deteriorate after an update. Default sampling parameters source have been updated in newer versions. For vLLM version 0.8.4 and higher, the default sampling parameters come from the generation_config.json file that is provided by the model creator. In most cases, this should lead to higher quality responses, because the model creator is likely to know which sampling parameters are best for their model. However, in some cases the defaults provided by the model creator can lead to degraded performance. If you experience this problem, try serving the model with the old defaults by using the --generation-config vllm server argument. Important If applying the --generation-config vllm server argument improves the model output, continue to use the vLLM defaults and petition the model creator on
texts.text: In some scenarios, the quality of the generated model responses might deteriorate after an update. Default sampling parameters source have been updated in newer versions. For vLLM version 0.8.4 and higher, the default sampling parameters come from the generation_config.json file that is provided by the model creator. In most cases, this should lead to higher quality responses, because the model creator is likely to know which sampling parameters are best for their model. However, in some cases the defaults provided by the model creator can lead to degraded performance. If you experience this problem, try serving the model with the old defaults by using the --generation-config vllm server argument. Important If applying the --generation-config vllm server argument improves the model output, continue to use the vLLM defaults and petition the model creator on

texts.label: text
texts.orig: to update their default generation_config.json so that it produces better quality generations.
texts.text: to update their default generation_config.json so that it produces better quality generations.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.4. CUDA accelerator errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.4. CUDA accelerator errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You might experience a self.graph.replay() error when running a model using CUDA accelerators. If vLLM crashes and the error trace captures the error somewhere around the self.graph.replay() method in the vllm/worker/model_runner.py module, this is most likely a CUDA error that occurs inside the CUDAGraph class. To identify the particular CUDA operation that causes the error, add the --enforce-eager server argument to the vllm command line to disable CUDAGraph optimization and isolate the problematic CUDA operation.
texts.text: You might experience a self.graph.replay() error when running a model using CUDA accelerators. If vLLM crashes and the error trace captures the error somewhere around the self.graph.replay() method in the vllm/worker/model_runner.py module, this is most likely a CUDA error that occurs inside the CUDAGraph class. To identify the particular CUDA operation that causes the error, add the --enforce-eager server argument to the vllm command line to disable CUDAGraph optimization and isolate the problematic CUDA operation.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You might experience accelerator and CPU communication problems that are caused by incorrect hardware or driver settings. NVIDIA Fabric Manager is required for multi-GPU systems for some types of NVIDIA GPUs. The nvidia-fabricmanager package and associated systemd service might not be installed or the package might not be running. Run the
texts.text: You might experience accelerator and CPU communication problems that are caused by incorrect hardware or driver settings. NVIDIA Fabric Manager is required for multi-GPU systems for some types of NVIDIA GPUs. The nvidia-fabricmanager package and associated systemd service might not be installed or the package might not be running. Run the

texts.label: text
texts.orig: to check whether the NVIDIA Collective Communications Library (NCCL) and Gloo library components are communicating correctly. On an NVIDIA system, check the fabric manager status by running the following command: systemctl status nvidia-fabricmanager $ systemctl status nvidia-fabricmanager Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow On successfully configured systems, the service should be active and running with no errors.
texts.text: to check whether the NVIDIA Collective Communications Library (NCCL) and Gloo library components are communicating correctly. On an NVIDIA system, check the fabric manager status by running the following command: systemctl status nvidia-fabricmanager $ systemctl status nvidia-fabricmanager Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow On successfully configured systems, the service should be active and running with no errors.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Running vLLM with tensor parallelism enabled and setting --tensor-parallel-size to be greater than 1 on NVIDIA Multi-Instance GPU (MIG) hardware causes an AssertionError during the initial model loading or shape checking phase. This typically occurs as one of the first errors when starting vLLM.
texts.text: Running vLLM with tensor parallelism enabled and setting --tensor-parallel-size to be greater than 1 on NVIDIA Multi-Instance GPU (MIG) hardware causes an AssertionError during the initial model loading or shape checking phase. This typically occurs as one of the first errors when starting vLLM.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.5. Networking errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.5. Networking errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You might experience network errors with complicated network configurations. To troubleshoot network issues, search the logs for DEBUG statements where an incorrect IP address is listed, for example: DEBUG 06-10 21:32:17 parallel_state.py:88] world_size=8 rank=0 local_rank=0 distributed_init_method=tcp://<incorrect_ip_address>:54641 backend=nccl DEBUG 06-10 21:32:17 parallel_state.py:88] world_size=8 rank=0 local_rank=0 distributed_init_method=tcp://<incorrect_ip_address>:54641 backend=nccl Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow To correct the issue, set the correct IP address with the VLLM_HOST_IP environment variable, for example: export VLLM_HOST_IP=<correct_ip_address> $ export VLLM_HOST_IP = < correct_ip_address > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Specify the network interface that is tied to the IP address for NCCL and Gloo: export NCCL_SOCKET_IFNAME=<your_network_interface> $ export NCCL_SOCKET_IFNAME = < your_network_interface > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow export GLOO_SOCKET_IFNAME=<your_network_interface> $ export GLOO_SOCKET_IFNAME = < your_network_interface > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow
texts.text: You might experience network errors with complicated network configurations. To troubleshoot network issues, search the logs for DEBUG statements where an incorrect IP address is listed, for example: DEBUG 06-10 21:32:17 parallel_state.py:88] world_size=8 rank=0 local_rank=0 distributed_init_method=tcp://<incorrect_ip_address>:54641 backend=nccl DEBUG 06-10 21:32:17 parallel_state.py:88] world_size=8 rank=0 local_rank=0 distributed_init_method=tcp://<incorrect_ip_address>:54641 backend=nccl Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow Specify the network interface that is tied to the IP address for NCCL and Gloo: export NCCL_SOCKET_IFNAME=<your_network_interface> $ export NCCL_SOCKET_IFNAME = < your_network_interface > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow export GLOO_SOCKET_IFNAME=<your_network_interface> $ export GLOO_SOCKET_IFNAME = < your_network_interface > Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.6. Python multiprocessing errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!
texts.text: 5.6. Python multiprocessing errors Copy link Link copied to clipboard!

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You might experience Python multiprocessing warnings or runtime errors. This can be caused by code that is not properly structured for Python multiprocessing. The following is an example console warning: WARNING 12-11 14:50:37 multiproc_worker_utils.py:281] CUDA was previously initialized. We must use the `spawn` multiprocessing start method. Setting VLLM_WORKER_MULTIPROC_METHOD to 'spawn'. See https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/getting_started/troubleshooting.html#python-multiprocessing for more information. WARNING 12-11 14:50:37 multiproc_worker_utils.py:281] CUDA was previously initialized. We must use the `spawn` multiprocessing start method. Setting VLLM_WORKER_MULTIPROC_METHOD to 'spawn'. See https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/getting_started/troubleshooting.html#python-multiprocessing for more information. Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow The following is an example Python runtime error: RuntimeError: An attempt has been made to start a new process before the current process has finished its bootstrapping phase. This probably means that you are not using fork to start your child processes and you have forgotten to use the proper idiom in the main module: if __name__ = "__main__": freeze_support() ... The "freeze_support()" line can be omitted if the program is not going to be frozen to produce an executable. To fix this issue, refer to the "Safe importing of main module" section in https://docs.python.org/3/library/multiprocessing.html RuntimeError: An attempt has been made to start a new process before the current process has finished its bootstrapping phase. This probably means that you are not using fork to start your child processes and you have forgotten to use the proper idiom in the main module: if __name__ = "__main__": freeze_support() ... The "freeze_support()" line can be omitted if the program is not going to be frozen to produce an executable. To fix this issue, refer to the "Safe importing of main module" section in https://docs.python.org/3/library/multiprocessing.html Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow To resolve the runtime error, update your Python code to guard the usage of vllm behind an if__name__ = "__main__": block, for example: if __name__ = "__main__": import vllm llm = vllm.LLM(...) if __name__ = "__main__": import vllm llm = vllm.LLM(...) Copy to Clipboard Copied! Toggle word wrap Toggle overflow

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When you run the Red Hat AI Inference Server container image, sometimes it is unclear whether device pass-through errors are being caused by GPU drivers or tools such as the NVIDIA Container Toolkit.
texts.text: When you run the Red Hat AI Inference Server container image, sometimes it is unclear whether device pass-through errors are being caused by GPU drivers or tools such as the NVIDIA Container Toolkit.
